Sure, here is the VPython code that simulates the horizontal projectile motion experiment you described with the specified settings:

```python
from vpython import *

# Screen Settings
scene.width = 700
scene.height = 400

# Cyber Input Variable Mapping Information
Height_I = 5

# Constants
g = 9.81  # acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2)
v0 = 10   # initial horizontal velocity of the ball (m/s)
t = 0     # time variable

# Objects
ground = box(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), size=vector(20, 0.1, 10), color=color.green)
ball = sphere(pos=vector(0, Height_I, 0), radius=0.5, color=color.red)

# Initial ball velocity components
vx = v0
vy = 0

# Main animation loop
while True:
    rate(60)
    
    # Update ball position
    ball.pos.x = v0 * t
    ball.pos.y = Height_I - 0.5 * g * t**2
    
    # Check if ball hits the ground
    if ball.pos.y - ball.radius <= ground.pos.y:
        vy = -vy  # Velocity inversion upon hitting the ground
    
    # Update time
    t += 0.01
```

This code sets up the VPython scene with the specified screen settings and simulates the horizontal projectile motion experiment as described. The initial height of the ball can be adjusted by changing the `Height_I` variable. When the value of `Height_I` changes, the animation will rerun with the updated initial height.
